title: Andy Burnham's Big Decision: To Run or Not to Run?
summary: Andy Burnham, the Mayor of Greater Manchester, has until Saturday to decide if he wants to run in a special election called a by-election in Gorton and Denton. If he wins, he could become a Member of Parliament and try to become the leader of the Labour Party, challenging the current leader, Sir Keir Starmer. But first, he needs permission from a group called the National Executive Committee (NEC) in the Labour Party. Some people in the party might try to stop him from running, which could upset others who support him. Andy Burnham hasn't said yet what he will do, but he is focused on his job as mayor. His friend Lucy Powell thinks he is a popular politician and should make his own choice. This election is important because it could affect who leads the Labour Party in the future.

background_read: In the UK, people vote in elections to choose leaders like mayors and Members of Parliament (MPs). A by-election happens when an MP leaves their job, and a new one needs to be picked. The Labour Party is one of the big political groups in the UK, and it has a leader who helps make decisions. Andy Burnham is a well-known politician who has been a mayor and might want to become an MP to have more power in the party.
Article_Structure: WHO: Andy Burnham, the Mayor of Greater Manchester, and other politicians like Sir Keir Starmer and Lucy Powell.
WHAT: Andy Burnham must decide by Saturday if he will run in a by-election to become an MP and possibly challenge for Labour Party leadership.
WHERE: The by-election is in Gorton and Denton, part of Greater Manchester in the UK.
WHY: To potentially become the Labour Party leader and influence politics, but he faces hurdles like needing permission from the NEC.

Others in the Labour Party might try to block him from running, which could cause arguments.
